head.title: Seizing the Day On Executive Pay

hedline.hl1: Seizing the Day On Executive Pay

block.p: Re ''More Pieces. Still a Puzzle.'' (Executive Pay: a Special Report, April 8), which described the new disclosure rules involving executive compensation:

Re ''More Pieces. Still a Puzzle.'' (Executive Pay: a Special Report, April 8), which described the new disclosure rules involving executive compensation:
Why did the Securities and Exchange Commission even bother installing such ludicrously tiny windows in the castle of executive pay?
The castle is still the castle; you need only view the manor to know who is still lord of the castle.

Labor costs for the rank and file are still viewed as a major reason for corporate poverty, yet very few people see executive compensation as a larger threat. It's time for the common peasants of corporate America to light their torches and to demand real executive compensation reform, before they're driven from the manor entirely.
There is a very simple solution to all the problems regarding executive pay -- and it would also help solve the worsening problems related to income distribution.

We need a law requiring C.E.O.'s and other highly paid executives to be paid only with a cash salary and a cash bonus. All other items typically included in executive employment contracts -- whether stock options, deferred compensation or retirement plans -- would be banned.
This change would enable everyone, including C.E.O.'s themselves, to quickly size up their pay.
Timothy Bal Belle Mead, N.J., April 9
